Award.AwardTitle: Summer School: Waves and Particles in Random Media, Theory and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides partial funding for the summer school "Waves and Particles in Random Media: Theory and Applications" to be held May 21-25, 2018 at Colorado State University, Fort Collins, Colorado. Study of waves and particles in random media is a domain of applied mathematics that involves a wide range of topics from various fields, such as electromagnetism, analysis of partial differential equations, inverse problems, probability and stochastic equations. The main objectives of the school are to offer a basic training in the field of waves and particles in random media in the broad sense, as well as to present the state-of-the-art and new directions of research. Besides the wealth of mathematical techniques, the topic also has a profound impact on many practical problems, for instance, on medical and radar imaging, underwater acoustics, non-destructive testing and seismology. The participants will also be exposed to a great variety of notions in cutting-edge research directions.Â 

Four distinguished invited speakers will give mini-courses on various aspects on wave propagation, from asymptotic theory to imaging techniques. Top researchers from applied fields involving wave phenomena, agreed to give special presentations. Some sessions of the Summer School will be reserved for young scientists to present their work. More information is available at:
http://math.colostate.edu/~pinaud/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A summer school in the field of Waves and Particles in Random Media was organized at Colorado State University in the summer of 2018. The duration of the school was one week. Four distinguished professors gave mini-courses and top researchers in the field gave special presentations. Some sessions were reserved for young scientists to present their work. About fifty people participated, for the most part associated with institutions within the United States, but also from abroad. The scientific background of the participants included mathematics, engineering, physics, and geosciences. 

The field of Waves and Particles in Random Media is an important domain of applied mathematics, and is related to many other branches of mathematics and physics. The study of Waves in Random Media is central in many different physical situations: electromagnetic wave propagation in the atmosphere, with applications to telecommunications and radar imaging; sound wave propagation in underwater acoustics, non-destructive testing in materials science; elastic waves in seismology.  While these problems are seemingly very different, they share a greatly similar mathematical structure. As a consequence, an understanding of the mathematics of waves and particles propagation in complex media is an important asset for young scientists, and this made the field a particularly well-suited subject for a summer school.
